Tuesday, July 19: 11:30 am - 2:00 pm Rideau
Canal/Dow s Lake Cruise

This is a 1.5-hour cruise
tour of the Rideau Canal by
Ottawa. The Rideau Canal is a
chain of beautiful lakes, rivers
and canals winding 202 km
from Kingston at the head of
Lake Ontario to Ottawa. This
cruise lets you discover the
Rideau Canal from Dow s
Lake to the Ottawa River.
You will enjoy viewing all the Z
interesting landmarks and gain insight into Ottawa s
rich history and heritage in this guided tour. The Rideau
Canal, the oldest continuously operated canal system in
North America, was built between 1826 to 1832. It is
a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is considered one
of the most remarkable engineering feats of the 19th
century. In the winter, it is the world s largest skating
rink! This tour is wheelchair accessible. Refreshments
are available for purchase on the boat. You will be
cruising onboard North America s largest and 100%
electric passenger vessel, which is the only one of its
kind!! www. ottawaboatcruise.com

On this tour, we leave the hotel in the afternoon and

heritage of Canada as well as supports related research.
The museum contains over three million artefacts and
documents, with some on display in the museum s
permanent exhibitions. One exhibit of interest to
Numismatists is The Rou  Collection   Bluenose and
Beyond. The collection helps tell the story of Canada s
best known naval architect and designer of many
vessels, including the iconic schooner Bluenose. We all
know that is the schooner displayed on the Canadian
ten-cent piece! www.historymuseum.ca .

A NEWLY DISCOVERED
COMMUNION_T OKEN

By ANGUS SUTHERLAND
#24054
Knox Presbyterian Church, Ripley, Ontario

Collectors of Communion Tokens tend to have it in
( the backs of their minds that new token discoveries

can come their way. Some previously undocumented
tokens have been found hidden away in back rooms or
basements of churches or dug up after being buried by the
elders of the congregations that used them. These tokens
have been considered special, even sacred, and they would
be somehow profaned by falling into the hands of collectors.
Occasionally a new discovery comes to light, as had
happened recently when the Presbyterian congregation in
Ripley, Ontario, decided to close.

It is fortunate that the people of Knox Church, Ripley,
chose to donate much of the church materials to the
Presbyterian Church Heritage Centre (formerly the National
Presbyterian Museum). Otherwise, the existence of the
tokens might never have been brought to light.

I work with the Heritage Centre overseeing the collection
of Communion Tokens and was contacted by the curator,
who believed he had a standard Free Church stock token
among the items from Ripley. In his email, he included a
photo of the token. I was immediately aware that this token
was a new discovery to the collecting community.

The curator s assumption was understandable. The token
does not include the town s name; it simply says  FREE
CHURCH 1844  on the obverse. The reverse contains one of
the standard Bible verses used on Communion Tokens:  Let
aman examine himself , followed by the reference,  1 COR.
XI. 28  (First Corinthians chapter 11, verse 28). There are,
however, no stock tokens of this type known.

So the question was, is this a previously unknown stock
token (I know of two that are unpublished in Canadian
references) or a token created for Knox Church Ripley alone?

Once I obtained a few examples, I realised the token
looked very familiar. It appears identical to the well-known

token of the Free Church in Pictou, Nova Scotia   the only
exception being the absence of the name PICTOU. Was there
some connection with Pictou?

The first clue to a connection was that there was one
example of the Free Church Pictou token among the tokens the
church still held; clearly, it was the model for the Ripley token.

The second clue came when I had the chance to visit the
church building before the final service, and in the entryway,
there was a stained-glass window to the memory of a Free
Church minister, the Rev. Alexander Sutherland. (Note: to
my knowledge, we are not related.) He served in Ripley from
1876 to 1897. His obituary indicates he began his ministry in
the charge of Earltown and West Branch, Nova Scotia, so the
token of Pictou Free Church would undoubtedly have been
known to him.

The church records indicate that the token indeed appeared
during Mr Sutherland s ministry. The conclusion, then, is that
Mr Sutherland, on arrival in Ripley, believed that the Ripley
congregation, formerly a Free Church, should have and use
Communion tokens. As a result, he had them made, modelled
after the Pictou Free Church token but removing the town s
name.

Looking at the surviving tokens, we find very few in good
shape, with wear and poor striking being the apparent cause.
Also, every token is made of lead, even though the Pictou
Free Church token is of white metal.
Specifications:

Obv: FREE CHURCH / 1844
Rev: LET A MEN / EXAMINE / HIMSELF / | COR. XI. 28
Measurements: 29.1 x 19.25 mm; thickness: 2.7 mm
Weight: 12.9 g; Metal: lead; Die Axis:  W coinage
Approximate date: 1877;
Minister: Rev. Alexander Sutherland The CN Journal Volume 67

THE CANADIAN NICKEL 5 CENTS
IS 100_YEaRsS_OLD abt airrere

Le 5 cents Canadien en nickel a 7 100 ans
Volume 42, No. 1, January, 1997, pp 13 24

Editor s Note: Yvon Marques first wrote this article 25 years ago for the CN Journal. It is reprinted here in an updated form.
* Note de la r daction : Yvon Marquis a  crit cet article il y a 25 ans pour le Journal CN. Il est r imprim  ici sous une forme
modernis e.
I n terms of dimension and metallic composition, the
5 cent piece as we know it today was introduced

100 years ago, in 1922. Before that date, the 5 cent
pieces were made of silver and were smaller than the 10
cent pieces.

As a matter of fact, since its introduction in 1858 and
up to and including 1921, the 5 cent piece was struck in
silver, and its diameter was only 15.5 mm. Its weight of
1.16 g was exactly half of the weight of the 10 cents.

In 1919, because the price of silver increased, the
government considered the possibility of modifying
the 5-cent coin, the beginning of the end for this small
problematic coin. It was easy to lose because it was so
small and so thin that it caused the production dies to
wear out prematurely.

The metallic content changed from .925 to .800
silver in the first attempt, but this was only a temporary
solution. As early as 1919, the government had
requested design suggestions from England to issue a
completely new coin as quickly as 1920.
Number 4 June
I a pi ce de 5 cents, tel que nous la connaissons
aujourd hui, en terme de grosseur et de composition

m tallique, a vu le jour il y a 100 ans, soit en 1922.
Avant cette date, les pi ces  taient en argent et  taient plus
petites que les pi ces de 10 cents.

En effet, depuis sa mise en marche en 1858, et jusqu en 1921
inclusivement, la pi ce de 5 cents  tait frapp e en argent et
avait un diam tre de seulement 15,5mm. Son poids de 1,16 g
 tait exactement la moitie de celui de la piece de 10 cents.

En 1919, en raison de la hausse du prix du m tal argent, on
 tudia la possibilit  de modifier la pi ce de 5 cents. C   tait la
le d but de la fin pour cette petite pi ce qui causait quelques
probl mes. Non seulement  tait-elle facile a  garer en raison
de sa petitesse, mais sa minceur provoquait aussi une usure
excessive des coins de fabrication.

Dans un premier temps, le contenu m tallique passa de
0,925 a 0,800 argent en 1920. Mais ce n tait la que mesure
temporaire, car d ja en 1919 le gouvernement avait demande a
l Angleterre de proposer des motifs avec I  intention d mettre
une nouvelle pi ce compl tement modifi e des que possible.
On souhaitait m me le faire des 1920.

A few designs submitted in 1920, but not retained for the new five cents coin issued in 1922. +
Quelque motifs soumis en 1920, mais non retenus pour la nouvelle pi ce de five cents  mise
(Library and Archives Canada, Finance Dept. fonds   RG19 V.423)

This new coin was introduced in 1922. It was round,
with a diameter of 21.21 mm and was made 100 percent
in nickel. Not only was the nickel a fraction of the price
of silver, but it was acknowledged worldwide as an
excellent metal for comage. In addition, Canada was the
world s largest producer of this metal. So, in 1922, nickel
was used to strike a Canadian coin for the first time.

Among the numerous entries, the design selected to
be used on the coin s reverse had been submitted by
W HJ Blakemore. It shows the word CANADA at the
top of the coin, with a large  5  in the middle, flanked
by the inscriptions  FIVE  at the left and  CENTS  at
the right. The date is at the bottom of the piece and is
separated from the  5  by two maple leaves. This design
was unmodified up to and including 1936. The obverse
remained as it was on the smaller silver coins, featuring
the crowned effigy of King George V facing left.

Among all the pieces issued between 1922 and
1936, only those issued in 1925 are rare. As a matter
of fact, only 201,921 coins were issued with this date.
Let s also mention that two varieties exist for 1926.

Cette nouvelle pi ce fut introduite en 1922. Elle  tait ronde,
avait un diametre de 21,21 mm et  tait faite de nickel 4 100 %.
Non seulement le nickel  tait-il moins dispendieux que l  argent,
mais il  tait reconnu dans le monde entier comme un m tal tr s
approprie pour le monnayage. Et de plus, le Canada  tait le
premier producteur mondial de ce m tal. C est done en 1922
que le nickel fut utilise pour la premi re fois pour la frappe
dune piece de monnaie canadienne.

Parmi les divers motifs soumis pour le revers de la pi ce,
celui retenu  tait  ceuvre de W H J Blakemore. Il montre le mot
 CANADA?  inscrit au haut de la pi ce, avec le chiffre  5  au
centre en gros caract re et encadre par les inscriptions  FIVE 
(a gauche) et  CENTS  (a droite). La date apparait au bas de la
pi ce et est s par e du  5  par deux feuilles d rable. Ce motif
demeura inchang  jusqu en 1936 inclusivement. Quant a l avers,
il demeura tel que sur les pi ces en argent, pr sentant | effigie
couronn e du roi Georges V face tourn e vers la gauche.

De toutes les pi ces  mises entre 1922 et 1936,
seule celle dat e de 1925 est rare. En effet, seulement
201,921 pi ces de cette date furent  mises. Mentionnons
 galement que deux vari t s existent pour |  ann e 1926.

' Two of the designs submitted for the new 1937
coins. We can see the caribou intended for the
five cents and the beaver for the ten cents. The
caribou was selected for the 25 cents.   Deux des
dessins soumis pour les nouveaux motifs de 1937.
On remarque le caribou pour le 5 cents et le
castor pour le 10 cents. Le caribou fut finalement
retenu pour la pi ce de 25 cents.

On the first variety, which is common, the tail of the
 6  is  near  to the maple leaf, while on the other
variety, which is scarcer, it is  far  from the maple leaf.

Following the accession to the throne of King
Edward VIII, Canada decided to take advantage of the
event to introduce entirely new reverse coin designs.
Both sides of the 5-cent coin were then modified in
1937. The obverse presents the uncrowned effigy
of the new monarch George VI who succeeded his
brother, who in the meantime had abdicated. The effigy
was prepared from a portrait of TH Paget (HP at the
truncation).

Sur la premi re vari t  qui est tr s courante, la pointe du chiffre
 6  est  proche  de la feuille d rable, alors que sur I  autre
variete, beaucoup plus rare, la pointe du  6  est  loign e  de
la feuille d rable.

Suite a I accession du roi Edouard VII au trone d  Angleterre,
le Canada d cida de profiter de 1  occasion pur modifier | 
ensemble des motifs ornant le revers de ses pi ces de monnaie.
Les deux c t s de la pi ce de 5 cents furent done modifi s a
compter de 1937. L avers montre |  effigie non couronn e du
nouveau souverain George VI qui avait succ d  a son fr re qui
avait entre temps abdique. L effigie fut r alis e a partir d un
portrait de T H Paget (HP sous le buste).
Number 4 June

It was initially decided that the caribou would be used
for the reverse of the 5-cent coin. But this design was
finally used on the 25-cent coin. A design submitted by
George E. Kruger-Gray for the 10 cent coin and showing a
beaver was then selected for the 5-cent coin. (see initials K
Gat the left of the beaver, over the water lines). The design
pictures a beaver on a rock-studded mound of earth rising
out of the water. The word CANADA is under the water
lines. While the date was at the top of the original design, it
was placed at the bottom under CANADA. The inscription
 5 CENTS  is at the top, flanked on each side by a small
maple leaf. When the new coin production began, there
were still some technical difficulties. The possibility of
striking the coin with an upset reverse, while Canadian
coins had been struck with straight reverses since 1908,
was even considered. But the problems were eventually
resolved without modifying the design. Let s note that
all of the 1937 dated 5-cent coins have a small dot after
the date. The exact reason for this dot is still a subject for
additional research.

This very popular and very  Canadian  design is still
used today, but it gave up its position to a few other
designs on a few occasions. Let s look chronologically at
the evolution of this coin and the modifications it suffered
through over the years.

The first major modification occurred in 1942. Because of
the need for nickel caused by World War Two, the government
decided that no more nickel would be used for coinage
until the end of the war. Various replacements were now
considered for the 5-cent coi, including an alloy containing
a small amount of silver which the United Stated had
adopted. This idea was ruled out, however, partially because
of its cost. Cupro-nickel was also considered but rejected,
and finally,  TOMBAC , an alloy of copper and zinc, was
chosen. Another modification also occurred. The coin, which
was round since its introduction in 1922, was modified to be
dodecagonal (12-sided), to avoid confusion with the cent.

On avait initialement pr vu que le caribou ornerait le revers
de la pi ce de 5 cents. Mais ce motif fut finalement retenu
pour la pi ce de 25 cents. Un motif montrant un castor et
soumis par George E. Kruger-Gray pour la pi ce de 10 cents,
fut retenu pour la piece de 5 cents (voir les initiales K.G.
a gauche du castor, au-dessus des lignes d eau). Le motif
montre un castor sur une motte de terre qui sort de l eau. Sous
les lignes d eau on retrouve le mot CANADA. Alors que la
date apparaissait au haut de la piece sur le dessin original, on

The new shape was inspired by the brass threepence

Meanwhile, work continued on new designs for the

As it is on all Canadian coins dated 1992, both
dates 1867-1992 appear on the five-cent
coins of this year. Let s remember that
1992 marked the 125th anniversary
of the Canadian Confederation, an
event that the government decided
to commemorate through several
souvenir coins.

The year 2000 was an
important year for numismatics
in Canada. At this time, the
Royal Canadian Mint once again
began changing the metal used for
minting circulation coins. A new
plating process had been developed to
reduce production costs, using steel as
the base metal. This core would be plated
either with copper or nickel, depending on the
coin. A small  P  (for Plated) was placed at the bottom
of the sovereign s effigy to differentiate these new coins
from the old ones. Thus, for 2000, we find 5-cent coins
dated 2000 struck in cupro-nickel (without P) or plated
steel (with P).

Puis, comme cela se retrouve sur toutes les
autres pi ces de monnaie canadiennes de
1992, on retrouve les dates 1867 et
1992 sur les pi ces de 5 cents de
cette ann e. Rappelons que 1992
marquait le 125e anniversaire de
la Conf d ration canadienne,

d cida de souligner par divers
programmes de monnaies
souvenir.
L ann e 2000 en fut
une importante sur le plan
numismatique au Canada. C est en

ces nouvelles pi ces des anciennes, on d cida d ajouter un petit

on retrouve pour I ann e 2000, des pi ces de 5  dat es de 2000
frapp es en cupro-nickel (sans P) ou en acier plaqu  (avec P).

In 2003, the government decided, during the  
year, to adopt a new effigy of the sovereign :
for Canadian coins. Usually, they waited
for the beginning of a new year to
introduce a new effigy, as was the

A commemorative 5-cent coin was issued in 2005 to
commemorate the 60th anniversary of the end of World

Then, on March 11, 2015, the Mint launched a
national contest inviting the public to create new

Our passions and Our Canada of

Mint and a jury of distinguished

in September 2015. The 2017 coins,

in their change menu next spring, will
therefore all display one of these patterns.

On November 2, the designs selected to adorm
Canada s 2017 circulation coins were unveiled.
Ceremonies were held simultaneously in the cities where
the winners lived.

In the Our Passions category, the public voted over a
million times and chose Gerald Gloade, a graphic
designer by profession from Millbrook First
Nation, Nova Scotia, as one of five
finalists. His design, which adorns
the reverse of the 2017 5-cent
circulation coin, depicts a solitary
beaver imbued with dynamism
and spirituality. It draws its
inspiration from its Algonquian
heritage in the forests of the
Northeast and the wildlife theme
that linked the commemorative
coins of Canada s centennial
in 1967. Created entirely with
digital tools, this reinterpretation of
one of our national emblems combines
tradition and modernity while emphasizing
the importance of First Nations cultures to Canada.

This completes our retrospective of the

includes many commemorative designs

and compositions. And, as one can see, the .
history of our  large 5 cents  1s directly related

Ten Contemporary Canadian Medallists
In the 1960s, Canadian art medals enjoyed a surge
in popularity domestically and worldwide. The first

documented cast art medal made in Canada was the
Canada Council Medal in 1961. A cast medal is made
by melting metal and pouring it into a mould rather than
striking it with dies. The casting process can produce a
larger product with much greater relief; and is the technique
preferred by many medal artists.

In 1963, Canadian medallists competed internationally
for the first time at the exhibition of the F d ration
International de la M daille. Their works were well
received, and Dutch and Belgian museums snapped up
many for their collections.

Art societies in Canada saw how popular our art medals
were on the world stage and changed their regulations to
make such displays easier here. Soon enough, Canadian
medals were being exhibited in Canada and at international
shows all over the world.

In 1971, the Public
Archives of Canada decided it
was time to hold an exhibition
devoted exclusively to
Canadian medallists. The
display was assembled with
the help of the Canadian
Sculpture Society and famed
medallist Dora de P dery
Hunt. Ten artists were
represented by over 200 of
their medals covering an
assortment of artistic styles
and techniques.

This exhibition was the first
time that the Public Archives
(now the National Archives
of Canada) held an exhibition
exclusively of Canadian
medals. It also served as an
introduction to the National
Medal Collection. The
archives had been acquiring
medals for its collection since
its founding in 1872 as the
Dominion Archives. Medals
serve as important documents
marking many historical
events in our nation s history.

Ten Contemporary Canadian Medallists is the program
that was made for the exhibition. It provides descriptions of
each medal on display and some biographical information
about each artist. Unfortunately, the catalogue is not
illustrated save for the medal on the front cover created by
Dora de P dery Hunt specifically for this exhibition.

Many numismatists are familiar with Dora de P dery
Hunt. She was the most prominent medallic artist in
Canada. Many collectors have examples of her work
without even knowing it. Her designs have been used
for many awards and medals. Some of the better-known
examples are the Toronto Zoo medal and the Hudson s Bay
Company s three hundredth anniversary medal. Her work
has appeared on many of our circulating coins, including
the version of Queen Elizabeth s image used on every
coin s obverse from 1990 to 2003.

This exhibition was a significant step in the growth of
medallic art and probably  
medal collecting in Canada.
Hundreds undoubtedly
visited the exhibition and
admired the beauty of these
small sculptures. This event
likely led many to fall in love
with art medals and decide to
form personal collections.

This catalogue makes a
good argument that medals
like the ones on display
at this show make art and
history more accessible to
the public.  Although many
of us would like to acquire
paintings or sculpture, few
of us are able to do so. All
of us, however, can collect
medals.  The medal is a
more accessible art form for
collectors. While paintings
can be copied, the originals
are the most sought after. On
the other hand, medals are
usually cast in large numbers.
Each cast piece is considered
an original, allowing a larger
group of collectors to own
the artist s work.

NOUVELLES. DES, CLUBS

By BRETT IRICK (CLUB SERVICES)
FRCNA, FONA, LM,#456

After two long years of the COVID-19, most clubs
are now meeting in person, with some meeting in a
live and virtual hybrid format.

For those interested in continuing a virtual
component, the RCNA Zoom meeting account
remains available to RCNA member clubs.
Meetings can be scheduled by e-mailing me at
xr7gt@prodigy.net or calling my mobile phone
(313) 207-3562.

We are looking for clubs to submit a short history
for use in this column. Many of our clubs have long
and unusual histories that have never been shared.

Club Delegates Breakfast Meeting Talk:
Navigating a Pandemic

The Waterloo Coin Society (WCS) has won the
Louise Graham Memorial Club of the Year Award for
its activities in 2021. Louise Graham, now deceased,
is a former RCNA executive secretary. The winning
club receives a $250 cheque, and an engraved silver
convention medal.

Fittingly, their president Tony Verbruggen will accept
the award. He also agreed to be the club delegates 
breakfast speaker. The title of his Friday, July 23 talk is
Navigating a Pandemic. He will present the actions the
WCS took over the past two years to strengthen the club
despite not being able to meet in person. The WCS was
an early adopter of Zoom virtual meetings and added
a monthly  coffee house  meeting for open discussion
plus show and tell.

These coffee houses have been so successful that
occasionally they last over three hours. And the WCS
has now picked up several new members from afar.

After Tony s talk, we plan an open discussion on how
other clubs adapted to survive the pandemic.

All convention registrants are welcome to attend the
Club Delegates Breakfast Meeting even if they are not
their club s official delegate.

The Hunt for New Meeting
Locations

Several clubs have been reporting on
their search for new meeting locations as
they transition back to live meetings. In
the reports, common themes are facilities
permanently closed with over 50 percent
increasing their room rental charges. Another
is moving traditional meeting dates because
the facility is closed several days per week.

BY SEAN SINCLAIR
#23912
Hero or Traitor   Perspective is Everything

harles de Gaulle is generally
( considered a national hero

in France but is somewhat a
polarizing figure here in our home
and native land.

His status in France is reinforced
by the fact that he has appeared on
four circulating commemorative
coins since 1988, three of which
have been produced since the
introduction of the Euro.

Charles Andr  Joseph Marie de
Gaulle was born in Lille, near the
border with Belgrum, on November
22, 1890. His mother, Jeanne
Maillot, came from a wealthy
family of mixed European heritage,
while his father, Henri de Gaulle,
taught history and literature.

Charles de Gaulle was the middle
of five children, with three brothers
(two younger and one older) and an
older sister. During dinner, the family frequently partook
in philosophical and historical debates, and young Charles
quickly developed a keen interest in history, particularly
military history.

De Gaulle completed his high school education at the
prestigious Coll ge Stanislas de Paris, a private Catholic
school in the French capital. De Gaulle won a placement
at the Ecole sp ciale militaire de Saint-Cyr in 1909,
ranking 119 out of 221 on the application exam. By the
time he graduated, he was 13th in the class.

In October 1912, de Gaulle joined the 33rd Infantry
Regiment as a sous-lieutenant under the command of
Colonel Philippe P tain.

The 33rd Regiment, considered one of the best in the
country, was sent to fight the German infantry at the
Battle of Dinant (August 15 to 24, 1914) at the outbreak
of World War I. De Gaulle was one of the first people to
be wounded, receiving a bullet to the knee on the first day
of fighting.

De Gaulle returned to the conflict in October as
Commander of the Seventh Company.

The unit became known for crawling into no man s land
to spy on the enemy, frequently returning with valuable
information. For this reason, de Gaulle was awarded the
Croix de Guerre on January 18, 1915.
Number4 June

Official portrait of Charles de Gaulle. (image:
  la Documentation francaise; photo: Jean-Marie Marcel)
a

On March 2, 1916, de Gaulle
was captured by German forces
during the Battle of Verdun after
receiving a bayonet to the left
thigh. He remained a prisoner of
war for the remainder of the conflict,
despite attempting to escape several
times. He returned to his family on
December 1, 1918.

With the outbreak of World War
II on September 1, 1939, de Gaulle
commanded the Fifth Army s tanks
in Alsace. In May 1940, de Gaulle
was given command of the Fourth
Armoured Division and engaged the
Germans on May 12 as they began
their invasion of France. De Gaulle
was given a field promotion to
Brigadier General on May 23, 1940,
a title which he retained for the rest of
his life. The rank became effective on
June 1, 1940.

France did not do well in the war. Paris was declared
an open city on June 10, 1940 (essentially surrendering).
An armistice was signed between Germany and the Third
French Republic on June 22, 1940, which de Gaulle refused
to acknowledge. He was stripped of his rank and forcibly
retired. By the end of June, however, the British government
reluctantly recognized de Gaulle as the leader of the Free
French forces.

Even in wartime, people questioned de Gaulle s abilities,
and his relations with other wartime leaders were hostile
at the best of times. As the war drew to an end, de Gaulle
served as the leader of the Provisional Government, although
very few leaders would accept this without a referendum. On
January 26, 1946, de Gaulle stepped down as the provisional
government leader, intending to write his memotrs.

His retirement didn t last long; following the collapse
of the Fourth Republic, a Fifth French Republic was
established on October 4, 1958. De Gaulle helped draft the
new republic s constitution and became its first President on
January 8, 1959.

What is likely his most controversial state visit during his
time as president was when he visited Canada during our
centennial celebrations in 1967. On July 24, 1967, de Gaulle
was at city hall in Montr al with Mayor Jean Drapeau when
he heard the crowds chanting for him in the square below.

In an unexpected move he asked to address the
crowd, at which point he went out to the balcony
and began speaking. His address, broadcast live on
the radio, concluded with  Vive Montr al! Vive le
Qu bec! Vive le Qu bec libre! Vive, vive, vive le
Canada frangais! Et Vive la France!

Prime minister Lester B. Pearson outright
condemned the address, and de Gaulle never did
arrive in Ottawa, boarding a military jet and
retuming to France on July 26.

De Gaulle resigned as president of France on
April 28, 1969, following the government s defeat
in a referendum. Charles de Gaulle passed away on =
November 9, 1970, after suffering an aneurysm, 13 days shy of his 80th birthday.
General de Gaulle on the balcony of Montreal City Hall, with his

wife Yvonne, Mayor Jean Drapeau and Marie-Claire Drapeau;
July 24, 1967. (Image: Montreal Archives; VM94, Ed37-21; CC BY-NC-ND 2.5 CA)

In 1988, the Monnaie de Paris struck a 1 franc
commemorative coin featuring Charles de Gaulle for
the 30th anniversary of the Fifth Republic. The reverse
\, design features five concentric hexagons, representing
the country s approximate shape. Centred inside
the hexagons is the denomination  1 F.  Along the
/ coin s outer rim is the motto
yf  LIBERTE EGALITE
FRATERNITE . The
Za bottom edge includes the
20 * AZ dual dates  1958   1988 
along with the privy marks of
the Monnaie de Paris and the mint
director. The obverse includes a right-facing portrait of de Gaulle, his name written along
the top of the design, and the legend  REPUBLIQUE FRANCAISE  along the bottom. The
two are separated by double-crossbar crosses, known as the Cross of Lorraine. A mediaeval

heraldic device, this cross became a symbol of Free France which de Gaulle adopted in his family
crest.
A commemorative 2 euro coin was released in 2010 for the
70th anniversary of de Gaulle s radio speech on June 18,

1940. During the speech, de Gaulle addressed the French
\ people from London, encouraging the French people to

3 resist the German occupation. It is considered one of
the most important speeches in French history.

A right-frontal portrait of de Gaulle is depicted on
the left side of the design, looking at his speech and
speaking into a period microphone. Legends on the

coin include the date at the top centre, followed by  70
ANS APPEL 18 JUIN . The usual two privy marks can
are located on either side of the date.

A joint French and German 2 Euro design was
released in 2013. The design celebrates the 50th
anniversary of the Elys e Treaty, which consolidated
the friendship between France and West Germany.

The Treaty was signed at the Elys e Palace in
Parison on January 22, 1963, by Charles de Gaulle
and German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. De Gaulle
is on the left, with Adenauer on the right, their
respective signatures below.

Flys e Treaty  is shown in French at the top of the
centre core and in German at the bottom.

Between the two portraits, in the centre, the legend
 50 / ANS / JAHRE / 2013 , signifying 50 years.
The French and German issues are identical, except
for the country of origin. France 1s identified by the
monogram  RF , while Germany uses a single  D 
for  Deutschland . The German coins also have
additional letters identifying the different mints: (A)
Berlin, (D) Munich, (F) Stuttgart, (G) Karlsruhe), and
(J) Hamburg.

A third 2 Euro coin featuring de Gaulle was
released in 2020. The coin celebrates the 130th
anniversary of his birth and the 50th anniversary of
his death.

Two right-facing portraits of de Gaulle are shown.
The portrait in the forefront is of his time as president,
while the background portrait depicts de Gaulle in his
military uniform; his name appears on the far right
side. The de Gaulle representative double-crossbar
cross appears on the left with a superimposed  RF ;
the  F  overlays the cross. The dual dates  1890 / 1970  are written on the left side of the cross, and  2020  on the right side.

. In addition to comage, de Gaulle s likeness has appeared
on a number of medals, like this one, produced by the
Monnaie de Paris in 1970 commemorating his death. The
34 mm medal was struck in .999 fine silver and gold,
featuring the Croix de la Lib ration ( Cross of Liberation )
with the legend PATRIAM SERVANDO VICTORIAM TULIT
which translates as  By serving the Fatherland, he/she
achieved Victory.

While de Gaulle s international legacy is undoubtedly
questionable, there is little doubt about his status in the Fifth
Republic.

A Numismatic DATE WITH History

By JESUS VICO
AND, MARISA. OLLERO,
June 4,

ttila, frequently called
Attila the Hun, was the
ruler of the Huns from

434 until his death in March
453. He was also the leader of a
tribal empire consisting of Huns,
Ostrogoths, and Alans, among
others, in Central and Eastern
Europe.

During his reign, he was
one of the most feared enemies
of the Western and Eastern
Roman Empires. He crossed
the Danube twice and plundered
the Balkans but could not
take Constantinople. His
unsuccessful campaign in Persia
was followed in 441 by an
invasion of the Eastern Roman
(Byzantine) Empire, the success
of which emboldened Attila
to invade the west. He also
attempted to conquer Roman
Gaul (modern France), crossing
the Rhine in 451 and marching
as far as Aurelianum (Orl ans)
before being defeated at the
Battle of the Catalaunian Plains.

He subsequently invaded Italy, devastating the northern
provinces, but could not take Rome. He planned for further
campaigns against the Romans but died in 453. After
Attila s death, his close adviser, Ardaric of the Gepids,
led a Germanic revolt against Hunnic rule, after which the
Hunnic Empire quickly collapsed.

There is no surviving first-hand account of Attila s
appearance, but there is a possible second-hand source
provided by Jordanes, who cites a description given by
Priscus.

He was a man born into the world to shake the
nations, the scourge of all lands, who in some way
terrified all mankind by the dreadful rumours noised
abroad concerning him. He was haughty in his walk,
rolling his eyes hither and thither so that the power
of his proud spirit appeared in the movement of his
body. He was indeed a lover of war, yet restrained
in action, mighty in counsel, gracious to suppliants
and lenient to those who were once received into his
protection. Short of stature, with a broad chest and

Certosa di Pavia   Medallion at the base of the
facade.  The Latin inscription tells that this is
 Attila, the scourge of God.  Carlo Brogi (1850
1925), Catalogue # 8227.
452 CE

a large head; his eyes were
small, his beard thin and
sprinkled with grey, and he
had a flat nose and swarthy
skin, showing evidence of
his origin.

Some scholars have
suggested that this description
is typically East Asian because
it has all the combined
features that fit the physical
type of people from Eastern
Asia, and Attila s ancestors
may have come from there.
Other historians also believed
that the same descriptions
were evident in some Scythian
people.

In 450, Attila proclaimed
his intent to attack the
Visigoth kingdom of Toulouse
by allying with Emperor
Valentinian IIT. Previously, he
had been on good terms with
the Western Roman Empire
and its influential general
Flavius A tius. A trus had
spent a brief exile among the
Huns in 433, and the troops that Attila provided against
the Goths had helped earn him the largely honorary title
of magister militum in the west. The gifts and diplomatic
efforts of Geiseric, who opposed and feared the Visigoths,
may also have influenced Attila s plans.

However, Valentinian s sister was Honoria, who had sent
the Hunnish king a plea for help and her engagement
ring to escape her forced marriage to a Roman senator in
450. Honoria may not have intended a marriage proposal,
but Attila chose to interpret her message as such. He
accepted, asking for half of the western Empire as dowry.

When Valentinian discovered the plan, only the influence
of his mother Galla Placidia convinced him to exile Honoria
rather than kill her. He also wrote to Attila, strenuously
denying the legitimacy of the supposed marriage proposal.
Attila sent an emissary to Ravenna to proclaim that Honoria
was innocent, that the proposal had been legitimate, and
that he would come to claim what was rightfully his.
(Image: Public Domain)
The CN Journal Volume 67

Attila returned in 452 to
renew his marriage claim
with Honoria, invading and
ravaging Italy along the
way. Communities became
established in what would
later become Venice due
to these attacks when the
residents fled to small islands
in the Venetian Lagoon. His
army sacked numerous cities
and razed Aquileia so entirely
that it was afterwards hard
to recognize its original site.
A tius lacked the strength
to offer battle but managed .
to harass and slow Attila s
advance with only a shadow -
force. Attila finally halted at

the River Po. Disease and starvation may have taken hold in
Attila s camp, thus hindering his war efforts and potentially
contributing to the cessation of invasion.

Emperor Valentinian III sent three envoys who met Attila
at Mincio in the vicinity of Mantua and obtained from
him the promise that he would withdraw from Italy and
negotiate peace with the Emperor. Prosper of Aquitaine
gives a short description of the historic meeting. Priscus
reports that superstitious fear of the fate of Alaric gave him
pause as Alaric died shortly after sacking Rome in 410.

Italy had suffered from a terrible famine in 451, and her
crops were faring little better in 452. Attila s devastating

not improve the harvest. To

The Huns, who had been plundering Italy and who

crushed, they made peace with the Romans and all
returned to their homes.

In Summer 2021, the Royal Canadian Mint identified an
ongoing counterfeit currency issue through their random
sampling process. The RCMP GTA-TSOC initiated an
investigation, focusing on identifying those involved in the
passing of the counterfeit coins.

Throughout the investigation, the RCMP seized
approximately 10,000 of this specific type of counterfeit
two-dollar coin, which had been placed into the Canadian
banking system. It is suspected that there are additional
counterfeit coins in the currency system and that the coins
originate from China. The seized counterfeit two-dollar
coins can be distinguished by their primary characteristic
flaw of having a  split-toe  on the night front paw of the
Polar Bear which resembles a  claw .

Daixiong He (age 68) of Richmond Hill, Ontario, has
been charged with:
Uttering counterfeit money, contrary to Section 452
of the Criminal Code; and

Possession of counterfeit money, contrary to
Section 450 of the Criminal Code.

Mr. He was arrested and released on an undertaking. Mr.
He s first court appearance will be held at the Ontario Court
of Justice located at 50 Eagle Street West, in Newmarket on
June 2, 2022, Courtroom 201 at 10:30 a.m.

These criminal charges are a reflection of the RCMP s
resolve in preserving the integrity of the Canadian currency
system. The RCMP is committed to working with the
Royal Canadian Mint, the Canada Border Services Agency
(CBSA), FINTRAC, banks, and municipal police partners,
to combat illicit efforts that target Canada s economic
system.    Supt. Ann Koenig, District Commander of the
GTA-TSOC Section.
